article.description: Erik Brown scored 17 points and Luke Whitehead added 15 as Louisville (No. 25 ESPN/USA Today, No. 19 AP) defeated Charlotte 80-59 Wednesday night in the Conference USA opener for both teams.
article.headline: Cardinals use 3-pointers to win eighth straight
article.linkText: Louisville wins Conference USA opener vs. Charlotte
article.story: CHARLOTTE, N.C. (AP) -- Louisville coach Rick Pitino credited this victory to 3-point shots -- the ones his team made and the ones Demon Brown missed. Erik Brown scored 17 points and Luke Whitehead added 15 points and a career-high eight assists as the Cardinals (No. 25 ESPN/USA Today, No. 19 AP) beat Charlotte 80-59 Wednesday night. Louisville connected on 14-of-29 3-point attempts compared with 2-for-17 for the 49ers in the Conference USA opener for both teams. Erik Brown's defense limited Brown, who averages close to five 3-pointers per game, to 1-of-6 shooting from behind the arc and 2-of-10 overall. "We shot the ball well,'' Pitino said, "but we felt the key to the game was holding Demon Brown under 44 percent shooting. When he shoots 44 percent or better, they win. When he doesn't, they lose.'' Reece Gaines contributed 14 points and Taquan Dean 11 for the Cardinals (9-1, 1-0), who ran their winning streak to eight games and evened the all-time series against the 49ers at 14 each. Curtis Withers scored 15 points and Tory Reed had 11 for Charlotte (5-7, 0-1), which lost its fourth straight. Louisville's 14 3-pointers established a record for an opponent at Halton Arena, breaking the old mark of 11. "We had 14 3s to their two,'' Pitino said. "With that kind of differential, you're going to win the game.'' The 49ers opened the second half with a 7-2 run and trailed 46-40 with 15:07 left after consecutive baskets from Withers. Gaines and Brown answered with 3-pointers from almost identical spots on the left wing, and Gaines added another 3-pointer with 13:38 left to give the Cardinals a 55-40 advantage. "They shot the ball incredibly well,'' said Charlotte coach Bobby Lutz. "Our guys made runs, but we weren't consistent enough to sustain what we had to do to beat a team like Louisville. "We forced some turnovers, and we had good play from Mitchell (Baldwin) and Withers off the bench, but we couldn't get over the hump, and part of it was just not being able to make shots.'' Baldwin had five points, five steals and three assists in 15 minutes. Charlotte took a 13-8 lead on Withers' dunk five minutes into the game, but Louisville ran off 12 straight points, including five from Whitehead and five from Dean. The 49ers closed to 23-21 on Eddie Basden's two free throws with 9:18 left before the Cardinals started a 13-1 spurt that put them ahead 36-22 on Larry O'Bannon's 3-pointer with 6:28 remaining. Charlotte scored three fast-break baskets during an 8-0 run that trimmed Louisville's lead to 36-30, but the Cardinals outscored the 49ers 8-3 in the last 3:06 of the first half to lead 44-33 at the break.
